required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Pulmonary Function After Arterial Sleeve Lobectomy
clinical_study.official_title: Perfusion and Functional Results After Pulmonary Artery Reconstruction During Oncologic Lung Resection

brief_summary.textblock:
Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death worldwide. Despite the evolution of medical and multimodal treatments, surgical treatment remains the curative management in the localized cancer.
Historically, in central lung tumors, pneumonectomy was the gold standard. Currently, bronchial sleeve lobectomy is recommended as first-line treatment over pneumonectomy when complete resection is possible (Grade 2C).
In the case of pulmonary artery invasion, lobectomy with arterial resection and reconstruction is now an accepted option for central localized cancer.
Despite surgical challenge, arterial sleeve lobectomy is oncologically comparable with pneumonectomy while avoiding the high morbi-mortality.
Indeed, this surgery has shown better results than pneumonectomy in terms of overall survival, post-operative mortality, and quality of life.
Initially performed in patients with impaired cardio-pulmonary reserves, this parenchymal sparing procedure can be realised in all patients, when anatomical conditions allow a complete resection.
In the literature, no study has yet specifically investigated postoperative respiratory function after arterial sleeve lobectomy.
The investigators designed a retrospective monocentric study at the University Hospital of Montpellier on 81 lobectomies with pulmonary artery sleeve resection for lung cancer, from January 2001 to December 2020.

primary_outcome.measure: Impact of pulmonary artery reconstruction on perfusion on the remaining lung lobe (ventilation/perfusion scan)
primary_outcome.description: Comparison of perfusion data on pre and post operative ventilation/perfusion scan

secondary_outcome.measure: Impact of pulmonary artery reconstruction on pulmonary function
secondary_outcome.description: Comparison of post operative predicted FEV1 to post operative FEV1
Patency data of the arterial reconstruction (thoracic angioscan)

secondary_outcome.measure: Pulmonary function according to the type of reconstruction
secondary_outcome.description: Comparison of the results (FEV1 ans patency) according to the type of reconstruction

arm_group.description: 81 patients who underwent lobectomy with pulmonary artery reconstruction during oncologic lung resection from January 2001 to December 2020

intervention.description: Lobectomy with pulmonary artery reconstruction under general anesthesia with selective intubation, by postero-lateral thoracotomy in the fifth intercostal space Subgroups : different types of pulmonary artery reconstruction such as : Tangential vascular reconstruction with direct suture Circumferential resection and end-to-end anastomosis bypass reconstruction with heterologous biografts, synthetic grafts, or pericardium patch

study_pop.textblock:
The study population includes 81 patients: 18 womens, 63 mens There was no significant difference in patient characteristics.
The most common resection was left upper lobectomy (52/81). 61 patients had a lung cancer with invasion of the left pulmonary artery.
The most common histology was squamous cell carcinoma (42/81). 28 patients underwent a double sleeve (angioplasty and bronchoplasty)
The type of arterial reconstruction was distributed as follows:
- 25 bypass
- 17 patch angioplasty
- 16 circumferential resection and end-to-end anastomosis
- 23 tangential vascular reconstruction with direct suture

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- all major lung resection with pulmonary artery reconstruction for lung cancer
- from January 2001 to December 2020 at University Hospital of Montpellier
- patient > 18 years
Exclusion Criteria:
0
